review.title: Statistical Analysis based Hypothesis Testing Method in Biological Knowledge Discovery
review.abstract: The correlation and interactions among different biological entities comprise the biological system. Although already revealed interactions contribute to the understanding of different existing systems, researchers face many questions everyday regarding inter-relationships among entities. Their queries have potential role in exploring new relations which may open up a new area of investigation. In this paper, we introduce a text mining based method for answering the biological queries in terms of statistical computation such that researchers can come up with new knowledge discovery. It facilitates user to submit their query in natural linguistic form which can be treated as hypothesis. Our proposed approach analyzes the hypothesis and measures the p-value of the hypothesis with respect to the existing literature. Based on the measured value, the system either accepts or rejects the hypothesis from statistical point of view. Moreover, even it does not find any direct relationship among the entities of the hypothesis, it presents a network to give an integral overview of all the entities through which the entities might be related. This is also congenial for the researchers to widen their view and thus think of new hypothesis for further investigation. It assists researcher to get a quantitative evaluation of their assumptions such that they can reach a logical conclusion and thus aids in relevant re-searches of biological knowledge discovery. The system also provides the researchers a graphical interactive interface to submit their hypothesis for assessment in a more convenient way.

Although interactions already discovered contribute to the understanding of various existing systems, researchers face many questions every day regarding interrelations between entities. Their queries play a potential role in exploring new relationships that may open up a new area of investigation. In this article, we present a text-mining-based method of answering biological queries with regard to statistical calculations, so that researchers can gain new insights. It makes it easier for the user to submit his query in natural linguistic form that can be treated as a hypothesis. Our proposed approach analyses the hypothesis and measures the p-value of the hypothesis in relation to existing literature. Based on the measured value, the system either accepts or rejects the hypothesis from a statistical point of view or does not find a direct relationship between the entities of the hypothesis, so that they can represent a comprehensive knowledge for researchers.

sections.heading: 3.1 Building Database
sections.text: The very first step of the proposed method is to build a database consisting of all possible relationships between different biological entities cited in an essay. We extract all possible types of must find out the semantic meaning of each line of this essay. If a line describes the positive relationship between the entities, the database stores the information with positive value. On the contrary: If the relationship described in one line indicates a negative relationship between the entities, the database stores the information with negative value. Each relationship cited several times in the essay is stored once in the database.

sections.heading: 3.2 Natural Language Processing
sections.text: The proposed system accepts the hypothesis to be tested in text format. Initially, we plan to work with a simple sentence consisting of two biological units and a verbal relationship between them. However, our system also works for any type of complex or compound sentence describing the relationship between the units. In order to find the supporting lines in different literature, our first step is to perform natural language processing so that we can extract the semantic meaning of these lines and thus be able to identify their actual role in supporting the given hypothesis. As, for example, an essay contains a line: "Protein A interacts with protein B." Since two units occur simultaneously in this line, our method can easily extract the relationship and store the information in the database. If one line describes the relationship in such a way that it is not obvious that the interaction of protein A with protein B really exists, "we will categorize the line as an opposite role to any relationship between protein A and protein B.

sections.heading: 3.3 p-value Calculation
sections.text: The statistical analysis of the hypothesis to be tested will be able to provide the user with a quantitative measurement of the hypothesis = In the proposed method, the hypothesis is processed and normalized through the processing of natural language in a manner discussed in the previous subsection. Basically, our aim is to test simple hypotheses that explain a relationship between biological entities. The normalization step marks the entity names expressed in the hypothesis and also finds the synonyms or aliases associated with the types of these entities from existing databases. The semantic meaning of the relationship is taken even after the containment of the verb and the necessary processing of the hypothesis. Our method then performs a database query to find out the role of the paper in supporting the given hypothesis. If it supports the hypothesis, the respective paper is counted as observed data for the p-value hypothesis.

sections.heading: 3.4 Biological Network Generation
sections.text: In this approach, we will not only evaluate hypotheses statistically, but also provide a biological network that surrounds the entities in which the researcher may be interested, and the biological network will help him or her to generate new assumptions that will further develop the prospective candidate, thus obtaining resources for further investigation. Essentially, the network centers around the entities mentioned in the test hypothesis, such as "Protein A interact protein B." Our tool will confirm the hypothesis and calculate the p value by means of chi-square testing. Furthermore, it will extract all other entities that cooperate with the protein A or protein B, or that build a bridge between them through transitive relationship. Graphically, the network will be presented to the user for convenience, in order to obtain a comprehensive overview of the relationships between the entities. Furthermore, the user will be able to generate new hypotheses by selecting the antecedents and then using the antecedents in the hypotheses.

sections.heading: 6 User Interface
sections.text: In order to make the tool available to the research community, we are developing a web-based tool HypoTest, which is shown in Fig. 1. First, the user can submit his query hypothesis in text form as in Fig. 1 (a). After submitting the query, the algorithm calculates the p-value in the background with respect to existing records and then displays the result on the following page as in Fig. 1 (b). The tool not only displays the p-value of the given hypothesis, but also generates a biological user as in Fig. 1 (c). This means that the user has two options to create the query hypothesis: he can submit the test hypothesis either in text form or in graphic format. The biological network extends the researchers "scope of thought and he can create new hypotheses for testing and exploring.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSION
sections.text: The paper describes a statistical approach to calculating the significance of the hypothesis submitted by the user, thus providing an opportunity to quantitatively measure the feasibility of the hypothesis. Furthermore, the method finds an interface for the greater convenience of the user, where he will also be able to graphically represent the query and visualize the biological network surrounding the entities of his interests. As a result, he will have scope to think further and generate new hypotheses from the network and iterate the process until he achieves satisfactory results. Our tool claims to be the first initiative in the field of significance measurement of the hypothesis. The graphical input system and biological network generation give the researcher flexibility and lead to a new way of thinking. In the future, we plan to work with complex hypotheses graphically and their significance calculation in the context of existing literature.

referenceMentions.context: In [1], authors are interested in formulating a hypothesis about the contribution of some novel genes in a disease by analyzing their co expression with genes already proved to be involved in that particular disease.
[2] Extracts the relation-ships among various biological entities from existing literatures.

ALIBABA [3] is an interactive tool that features several aspects including a graphical display of network consisting of all the extracted relationships of the queried entity with other entities cited in the publications.
iHOP [4] is another tool that integrates information about genes and makes a way for easy navigation from one gene information to another by hyper-linking particular corpus to the specific gene name.
BioIE retrieves abstracts from PubMed based on a keyword query and then identifies and extracts informative sentences using rule and pattern based methods [6].
EBIMed [7] retrieves a set of abstracts as a result of keyword search and then filters for sentences containing UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot proteins, GO terms, drugs and species.

HubMed [9] is a web based biomedical literature search platform where users get an integrated interface equipped with a number of features for visualizing clusters of related articles and doing other supporting activities.
The exploratory tool XplorMed [10] has been developed to analyse the result of any MEDLINE query.
[11] provides an evolutionary technique to generate and test hypothesis on the basis of the number of documents supporting the hypothesis and the relationship strength as retrieved by Chilibot.
BioGraph [12] provides an online resource and data mining method for the automated inference of functional hypotheses between biomedical entities.
Another method builds a disease-gene network based on dependency parsing and support vector machine and then measures some statistical metrics to rank the genes in the network [13].
[14] introduces a tool CoPub Discovery that mines the literature for new relationships between genes, drugs, pathways and diseases.

Integrated Bio-Entity Net-work [15] is a recent framework that incorporates graph theoretic algorithms like Breadth- rst search with pruning (BFSP) and most probable path (MPP) algorithms to assign weight to the curated relationships and thus generate hy-pothesis from the existing literatures.
